text: Family Member 1: I see. Doctor: So it’s, But it’s irrelevant. The cancer’s out. It’s an aggressive cancer. Family Member 1: Um Hmm. Patient: What are the side effects from the chemo and super hormones? Doctor: Yeah, uh so the biggest side effect, quite frankly, so let’s talk about hormones first. Uh because the super hormones don’t add anything. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, but hormone therapy, uh as far as I’m concerned, it’s the worst part of the whole thing, right. It’s gonna put you into menopause, it stills your sex drive, it gives you hot flashes, and it slows your metabolism by you know twenty-five percent, so you have to decrease your calorie intake. And you have to exercise like a fiend, or you’re going to get fat, and you don’t want that. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um but the other thing is it just makes you more tired, you know. We’re making you into an eight-year-old guy – Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: -temporarily. Family Member: For two years.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we call that micro metastatic cancer. Patient: All right. Doctor: Has spread somewhere else, but it’s so tiny, microscopic that we cannot find it on the scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And in the past we did have two areas that lit up on the bone. Patient: Right. Doctor: We had the bone scan and you had both of those areas radiated at the same time as getting the hormone therapy. Patient: Correct. Right. Doctor: So it’s possible that those would not be visible at this time. Or it’s possible that they still might be visible and it’s also possible that new areas you know might have popped up somewhere else in different bones or different areas like lymph nodes which were not there before. So it’s very important you know once the PSA reaches one that we basically establish what the extent of your cancer is at that point in time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, um, the standard recommendation for you at that point would be to go back uh on a hormone therapy. Patient: Uh huh.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Can I tell you how much that’s gonna increase the fifty/fifty odds? No. Can I tell you that that’s the most aggressive thing we can do for this cancer right now anywhere in the world? Yes. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s what you know basically how I take care, how I try to take care of guys like you who are young and I want to hit the cancer really hard. Patient: Right. Doctor: So your choice basically is radiation with hormones or if you want to try a super sort of therapy, with chemo, super hormones, we can do that. Patient: Okay. Family Member 1: Yes, super hormones uh for what duration? Doctor: We, uh I give them for three months for four doses of chemo three weeks apart. Family Member 1: And let me ask you um, Are there any treatments that you use with the PSMA that targeted those cells, um? Doctor: Um yes, so, so, you’re talking about like PSMA radionuclide therapy and um right now there are a couple of clinical trials in the United States for guys who have failed hormone therapy. There are also – um you can do that – I’ve sent probably; uh I’ve sent twelve guys over to Germany to get that therapy in the last eighteen months uh you know specifically to try and like avoid like hormone therapy or something. What I can tell you is in this setting that therapy is not curing anybody. So if you’d asked me eighteen months ago, I would have said sure, let’s send you over there. What I’ve learned in the last eighteen months is that nobody I’ve sent over has been cured by that therapy, and uh I don’t consider it worthwhile right now. Family Member 1: Okay, and then the other question was - I don’t know if this makes a difference or not, Do we have a Gleason score of the margins that were left? Doctor: So it’s and uh irrelevant and undoable because you know the therapy he received, uh we wouldn’t uh it’s not scored.

text: Patient: Okay. Now, so, along with what we’ve talked about, if we decide that, uh, uh, the, uh, the clinical trial is not working- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: Then, what I’m going to do is go back to K___? And so J___ H___ will not be involved anymore after that? Doctor: So let’s talk about that for a second. So there are two main options. One is that if you wanted to pursue a standard therapy, such as enzalutamide, also called Xtandi, or chemotherapy, that would be through K___, because as a standard therapy, you will not have privileges, unless you paid out of pocket, to come here for that therapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: On the other hand, the second possibility is to participate in a different clinical trial. So I’ll give you one example. So we have a trial right now testing immunotherapy against prostate cancer. That is a drug that stimulates your own immune system to hopefully fight and kill the cancer. Okay? That’s just one example. We might have at least one more trial that you’re also eligible for. But both of these trials would not really rely on that mutation, specifically, but they are just trials that you would still qualify for, uh, independent of the mutation. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: If you decided to participate in a different clinical trial, then, of course, you could receive that therapy here as long as K___ approved of you to enroll in that trial, which they probably will, because their general policy is if you’re participating in a trial at an institution that’s not available through K___, then they support that. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So you could definitely still be our patient, and we would love it if you were. Uh, we’ve gotten to know you for the past several months, and I think your experience with us has also been relatively good. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so, you know, that could be a win-win, but we have to make sure that it’s something that makes sense for you. We’re not going to put you on a trial just for the sake of keeping you at H___.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So you’re going after them just because you can see it but there is no guarantee that what we can see on the CAT scan is the only place at this point in time where the cancer is at. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: So we might graph that lymph node and your PSA might drop by fifteen percent, then we’ll know in retrospect had we got that lymph node we might have actually killed all of the cells in that lymph node - Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and yet your PSA might drop by fifteen or twenty-five percent. And so what we’ve learnt the hard way, so-to-speak with experience, is that although we can do that, it is technically feasible -um and there are some types of radiation that can be reimbursed by insurance companies, for example - Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - um we have not seen cases where that is curative. That is also another type of therapy that delays the progression of the cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So so for example, if your primary goal was to delay hormone therapy for as long as possible, like if you really wanted at all cost to avoid hormone therapy - Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: - the one thing that we could consider would be referring you to a radiation oncologist that specializes in the type of radiation called stereotactic radio therapy, which is a very sort of focused -

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
